pros: A healthy place to work with a nice and friendly employee
cons: Not so much a good weather environment. gets really cold sometimes

job_title: Adjunct Mathematics Instructor in Fort Polk, LA
pros: Adjunct pay is 700 per credit hour. Courses are already pre-loaded and ready to go. Technology support for faculty is great.
cons: Most students are used to getting a passing grade for showing up. Some don't show up and still expect to pass. I feel like this is a degree mill and it's common knowledge that a degree from here is a joke. No one really has to "earn" their degree. Sad.

pros: Loved the team. Ample parking around town.
cons: It is with great sadness that we see the writing on the wall for this once-average institution. Instead of "Feathers Up," the motto should be "Do More With Less." Here you'll find a weird mix of employees who do the work of two or three people and others that do nothing at all. Is bad leadership to blame? Absolutely. But it's also... ~ Crippling debt ~ Rural campus setting ~ Lack of a cohesive marketing strategy ~ Low ratings everywhere ~ Poor reputation management ...that are contributing to the demise of UIU. What's out there? ~ BOTTOM 25% of Regional Midwest Universities (U.S. News & World Report) ~ 1.9 star Rating from employees (Glassdoor, 110+ reviews) ~ 1.9 star Rating from women (InHerSight, 130+ reviews) ~ F- Rating for Value (CollegeFactual Scorecard) ~ Multi-million dollar deficits for the last five years (IRS)

review_title: Students, faculty and staff – stay away!
pros:
Small town charm

Everyone knows you if you like that kind of thing

Get in good with the right people and you're golden
cons:
This school is struggling.

In 2022 Forbes gave UIU a financial GPA of 1.11 and a grade of D.

The financial position is precarious and the school took out an enormous loan of $70+ million that they keep deferring payments on.

Enrollment has declined precipitously and there are noticeably fewer students on campus. This has a snowball effect and there are even less things to do and worse turnout.

Upper administration has never been a strength here, but they are unprofessional and unqualified.

There are superstars in all departments, but the good and competent people get dumped on and asked to do more and more.

Normal things like ROI are not measured and used to inform future decisions. Thousands of dollars are set on fire by doing silly things like an Iowa State Fair booth. It wastes time, money and resources.

In the last 8 years, the Board of Trustees fell asleep while the school racked up massive deficits, then canceled a presidential search and appointed an internal candidate. They are now just sitting by while the school continues to nosedive in enrollment, staffing, and online reputation. You’ve got to govern the place and not just show up for your goodie bag a couple of times a year!

job_title: Facilities OFfice Manager in Fayette, IA
pros: Good work group and less demanding than most office manager positions
cons: In Fayette Iowa and under paid

pros: Good and supportive student life staff
cons: Upper management is not interested in academics

review_title: This place is a joke, but no one's laughing
pros:
There are a few good apples among the rotting bushels.

I went here for school, was a student worker, and then hired on in a full-time role.

This is a similar trajectory to a lot of people who work for Upper Iowa.

Classes are easy, instructors don’t care. You can get a degree with little effort, but be prepared to graduate with few job skills.
cons:
It's bad leadership, plain and simple. They delegate everything and throw their team under the bus when things don’t go well. VPs are "so busy" but somehow are constantly surprised by news from their direct reports because they're not on top of things.

There are hires based on their last name or who they’re friends with, not on merit. This happens everywhere to an extent, but the problem at Upper Iowa is that the nepotism hires don’t know how to do their job. On second thought, maybe this is more comforting for THE BAD LEADERSHIP, because they also don’t know how to do their job.

pros:
Some staff: Try their best with a smile on their face.

Some leadership: Believe that they can truly effect change even in the face of challenging odds.
cons:
Some staff: In a competition to see who can do the least amount of work.

Some leadership: The vice presidents in charge of enrollment management and external affairs/marketing are up a creek without a paddle. Enrollment keeps dropping and their strategy is to burn money with agencies. The agencies are just chasing a payday, and leadership is out to lunch at the Servery.

review_title: Led for all the wrong reasons
pros: Hardworking and dedicated faculty members.
cons: Bad administration and board of trustees. Employees are replaceable according to them.

review_title: The struggle is real and the future is bleak
job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Fayette, IA
pros:
Benefits including generous PTO.

Helping students is fulfilling.
cons:
The VPs here are incompetent and would be eaten alive outside of the small town of Fayette.

The institution has literally mortgaged its future with a $70+ million loan secured by Fayette campus assets.

There have been multiple payment deferrals while interest continues to accrue.

Very little financial transparency or any transparency, for that matter.

There are serious doubts whether or not the school will continue to exist in the next 3 to 5 years.

Large exodus of faculty and staff in recent years, a vicious cycle of no continuity and new staff constantly playing catch up.

pros: Dedicated alumni and Fayette campus
cons:
Toxic culture, Bad leadership, High turnover, Low morale.

Too many cooks in the kitchen re: Marketing the university. Inconsistent branding. Either fire the marketing staff and go with a schoolwide vendor or get out of the way and let them do their job. As of this writing, there has been no director of that dept for 8 mos! Tired of seeing every piece from our department look different depending on who worked on it.

Enrollment is down and tantrums are being thrown. Multiple years with continuing deficits. Backing up the money truck for vendors with no ROI attached. 

Serious issues of conduct "handled internally" or swept under the rug.

Many friends and colleagues have left for greener pastures & I'm about to join them. Job seekers: a generous $45k position at a failing institution can be yours!

review_title: Ain't what she used to be
pros:
The only game in town for a semi stable job

was proud as a peacock to work here

Nice colleagues who suffer with you

Campus is nice, esp if you are in one of the newer bldgs
cons:
A cluster of bad upper management, disconnected faculty and no vision for the future

Faculty have 0 confidence in leadership

Work from home is like pulling teeth (it's 2022, not 1922)

Ain't nothing to do in Fyette

Money is tight and everyone knows it

Revolving door of ppl leaving just stop putting departures in the monthly newsletter bc it's depressing

This place used to be great but that time has passed

review_title: The Great Resignation started years ago here
pros:
* OK benefits

* Can phone it in at work

* Real diversity and inclusion efforts made
cons:
* Poor leadership by vice presidents

* Please stop hiring your friends, "leadership"

* Hire people who actually know how to do their job

* Behind the times on everything

* Very high staff turnover rates

* Squandered early lead in online education

* Pay and morale is awful

* Disparage people that leave, rather than looking inward at your screw ups

review_title: Calling it a disaster is being generous
pros:
slow work pace

early out at 3 pm on friday

leadership is clueless, easy to skate under the radar + do very little work
cons:
jiu is an epic fail on many levels starting with bad and clueless leadership

just the facts...

million dollar deficit$ year after year

double digit employee turnover rates above industry averages

financial health of the school is poor (cfi)

pros: UIU affords many lateral opportunities within the firm but many of them are restricted to the primary campus. Even within the outlying centers there are opportunities for growth.
cons: The policies & procedures have not adapted very well to the changing work climate with very few remote positions available. Pay has not kept step with the passage of time, but the benefits are extraordinary.

pros: Get paid, Student athletes are grateful to be here, Work life balance is ok
cons:
Abhorrent upper management.

Rampant favoritism. 

Boring small town with nothing to do and no redeeming qualities.

Promotions handed out to lazy idiots.

Antiquated tech. Internal school portal (myUIU) looks like it's from 1995.

Multiple coaches, deans, and directors out in the last few months.

Dwindling student population on campus = sad ghost town

Social media is a dumpster fire. Uninspiring and unoriginal.

review_title: Get out while you still can
pros:
Helping students

Mix of new and old buildings with character

Hiring standards are low due to the remote campus location so if you are halfway decent you can get a job
cons:
UIU can't you see, the signs are calling?

A school like you, should have a warning.

It's dangerous, the ratings are falling.

...and I love what I do

But does UIU know that it's toxic?

pros: Leaving UIU was the best day of my life.
cons:
If you’re looking for a job that will make you sad, this is the place for you!

Some Vice Presidents make over $100k while running the school into the ground.

This place is not a family, it’s a clique.

If you are tight with the right peeps, you’re good.

If not, good luck getting a raise or promotion.

Staff turnover is high and morale is low.

I should have listened to my gut.

Wasted time at this dead end.

I ignored the red flags, but let my mistake be a lesson!

pros: The institution really tries to keep afloat; it is in a very small, rural community which might have its advantages for individuals who are drawn to this context.
cons: Extremely micromanaged, run by people who do not have experience in other institutions or states. Some employees even describe the work place as very toxic. Not much room for development. It's their way or the highway. The institution has had an impressive amount of faculty members who have quit.

pros: Coworkers, family atmosphere, benefits, flexibility
cons:
No incentives. No raises hardly
Taken advantage of, high turnover rate

pros: Most faculty are good, honorable people. Good students overall and nice campus and accommodations.
cons: Administration has contentious view of faculty. Turnover is high, new Provost almost yearly. New Provost is lacking in many key areas of leadership. President is surrounded by “yes”’people. Nepotism is historically rampant in many levels.

pros: The department of facilities is friendly and everyone works together as a team, any problems and suggestions are taken quickly to resolves problems.
cons: The department is always handicapped by the upper management, during crucial times like covid, questionable decision was made resulting in high turnover for our department.

pros: Enjoyed the environment. Friendly people
cons: Classes one day a week

pros: I have taught online courses for UIU for the past six years, and enjoyed the support of administrators who had to field complaints that my classes were too rigorous. Defending college level standards is important to me, since dumbing down curriculum harms everyone, and is not fair to students who are paying a premium price for an excellent education. Many of the students I have taught at UIU have expressed appreciation for my teaching methods, and many have gone on to promotions and raises all because they learned to write better from my classes.
cons: Recently, people who are not Subject Matter Experts in my field have presumed to tell me how to teach my online class, including going so far as to tell me how I should be teaching grammar in my English classes, instead of trying to understand why I teach it the way I do. Several other online faculty have complained that they feel the micro-managing of the classes is detrimental to their abilities to teach their courses to the best of their abilities, but all our complaints seem to fall on deaf administrative ears.

pros: Loads of work to do
cons: Very slow paced work environment

pros: The work environment is very friendly
cons: There were not any issues with my work experience

job_title: Academic Advisor in Des Moines, IA
pros: Fair Workload and great students
cons: Micro managing at times by upper management.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Fayette, IA
pros: Flexible work schedule with a good learning experience
cons: Limited opportunities available at the University

pros: Remote work available for some. Co-workers bond over misery.
cons: Zero raises in 4 years. Zero professional development. Management changes their mind a lot due to whim not facts. Enrollment down so layoffs are common.

pros: Students were friendly and grateful for a quality instructor
cons: Supervisors, chain of command, environment

pros: great environment, great people, great opportunities
cons: cant think of anything, everything was great

job_title: Phonathon Student Caller in Fayette, IA
pros: Nice, can work around school
cons: There are no cons to them.

review_title: UIU is a place I call home.
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Fort Leavenworth, KS
pros: One of the few universities offering accelerated programs that actually still value academic standards and don't just push students through because their checks clear.  While I cannot speak directly to the main campus, at my satellite campus, faculty are treated as valued and respected members, whose contributions are necessary for the longevity of the university.
cons: The main campus has bizarre criteria for assigning classes.  For example, I have an engineering degree and 20 years experience teaching undergraduate and graduate statistics, as well as numerous published articles on the subject, and yet am not allowed to teach statistics, because I don't have a "math" degree.  Likewise, they won't hire a colleague of mine to teach criminal justice, despite him being an accomplished defense attorney, but they will assign the class to someone with a degree in sociology.

pros: The bosses at the eLearning/online department are really nice and fun, some they there were cookies and IEC, where most of the business people work, has a small snacks sale everyday. Hours were flexible too. If you are a full time, you get to work on your education with huge discounts too.
cons: All employees have been given many more tasks than they can accomplish, so things don't really move forward. They have been trying lots of different changes lately on positions and locations.

pros: Working relationship with co-workers. Opportunity to be involved in the community. Premier relationship with working adults seeking college degrees. Great adjunct faculty.
cons: Insufficient clerical support, some reports time-consuming and superfluous, very political "us and them" mentality between the home campus and remote centers, poor level of service from campus resources for remote centers, weak student information infrastructure. Mistakes by some not remediated but mistakes by others result in termination--unbalanced execution, lack of consistency. On-campus faculty hold too much power and influence.

review_title: The people I work with are friendly supportive and helpful. It allows me to use my skills while also building new ones.
job_title: Student Financial Services Specialist in Fayette, IA
pros: I love the short commute, the people I work with, and the work culture (in general be kind to everyone aka golden rule). Tuition remission is available to employees, spouses, and dependents.
cons: No flex time.  We currently don't get raises but we're are provided just perks. I play nothing for insurance (single plan) and UIU puts money in my HSA.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Milwaukee, WI
pros: The campus of the main university is beautiful, and the main staff on that campus is personable and helpful.
cons: The hierarchy dealing with the satelite campuses is top down, and rigidly maintained to the extent that an employee can be fired for speaking to anyone but their direct supervisor if they have a complaint. If the supervisor is the problem, there is no recourse.

review_title: Good for a while; institution is slipping now...
pros: Adequate infrastructure in the main location.  Some employees have been there for decades and are very loyal.
cons: High levels of suspicion and mistrust; little sense of employees that executive level has vision.  Organizational climate is destroyed now; too many interim positions with no knowledge of UIU.  Financial woes resulted in suspension of TIAA-CREF.

review_title: University is in big trouble. Can it pull out?
pros: These are hard to come by these days. Working with students is the pro, although they are also reacting negatively to the current culture. Many are transferring due to an increase of almost 10% in tuition and fees and the cutting of programs and termination of good professors.
cons: Little faculty input for curriculum-power is now in  the deans, provost, and BOT to cut or add programs. If they like you, they keep our program even if there are a few majors. If they don't like you and the program is big, they are still cutting the program and terminating faculty. Faculty given terminal contracts this year had excellent yearly and 3rd year reviews. When called into HR, the dean read from the newly imposed faculty handbook (created by interim dean and BOT friendly faculty chair over one summer without input from rest of faculty) the section stating that the admin doesn't have to tell them why they are getting a terminal contract. New faculty handbook states that we follow AAUP guidelines until it conflicts with the absolute power of the administration when it comes to treatment of faculty. Talk of transparency is big but is a joke. 4 required "furlough" days for faculty that aren't actually days off; no retirement match with no renewal in sight; current climate being hidden by some admin during new searchers. The faculty that can leave are leaving or looking to leave, even if they didn't get a terminal contract. Apathy rampant in larger numbers of faculty and staff.

pros: UIU allows the young professional the ability to "wear many hats." This is a unique attribute of the institution and provides many various experiences as well as the ability to learn in a variety of different roles within the institution.
cons: Leadership goals are not clear. Some individuals in leadership roles appear to have no experience or credentials. Some new positions are not advertised; just filled.  High turnover. Small rural area.

pros: Lite workload, nice southern charm to the town, friendly staff.
cons: Basic needs for development and fundraising hard to come by. Archaic database and incompetent staff on the development side. Low pay for the location of the university and the amount of hours on the road.

pros: The people you work with are super friendly and just will make you feel at home. Cost of living is very low so your low salary goes a long ways in a single household
cons:
Very small town with not a lot of places to eat
Low salary

review_title: Some good and some really bad managers
pros: Good people, nice campus, good quality of work, good employee wellness initiatives.
cons: Bad politics, controversial arguments, misaligned goals.

pros: I love teaching the UIU students! Some are military so classes are very diverse. It's a great school.
cons: I have worked at UIU for over 6 years and I cannot think of any CONS at this job.

pros: Helping students.  That's about it.
cons: Very political. Some faculty very competent, but all too often, senior faculty making decisions are incompetent.  Financial woes resulted in incompetent BOT and  administration unilaterally making (poor) decisions (small comfort that incompetent senior faculty are now suffering).  Absolutely do not advise anyone taking a job at this place.

review_title: Extremely underpaid for Information Technology workers
pros: Very low stress compared with public sector
cons: About $35,000.00 less than going rate for Information Technology workers

pros: Great support from leadership and Dean.
cons: I do not have any cons with this university.

pros: Enthusiastic organized intelligent trustworthy current

pros: The staff is very friendly, accommodating and well organized.

pros: Excellent course designers to customize the online class.

cons: Location isn't the best for young professionals.

pros: Great love the place it is great

pros: Administration is very supportive of staff.

pros: super, dedicated staff committed to students
